text: Good Morning America Blizzard emergency
America's East Coast gripped by a huge
snowstorm expected to bring
unprecedented disruption shutting down
across a vast area a state of emergency
has been declared schools closed flights
canceled rail lines shut down and people
told to stay at home all in anticipation
of as much as two feet of snow we're
seeing the everything line up for a
major storm system affecting the eastern
third of the country and affecting at
least 50 million people with heavy snow
and cold temperatures and very strong
winds given the significant severity of
the forecast we will treat this event as
a homeland security and Emergency
Management event in the District of
Columbia for many being prepared means
going shopping panic buying has seen
shelves left empty as people stocked up
for what could be a difficult few days
we're just going to cook and play board
games all weekend it should be fun we're
buying provisions for the family of four
and assuming we'll hunker down here for
a few days there's already been a light
dusting that paralyzed road networks are
causing traffic chaos and plenty of
bumps and scrapes and the impact goes
all the way to the top even the
commander-in-chief almost wrong-footed
the presidential motorcade never
normally held up for anything stuck in
one of the jams the authorities are
already apologizing for the slow
response we don't believe that we
prepared adequately for a forecast that
was was slightly less than what we got
at rush hour and we should have been out
earlier with more resources look how big
this is
so now millions are keeping an eye on
the forecasts hoping to be better
prepared this time but the snow is
already falling and it's likely to have
a major impact across a large area Dan
Johnson BBC News
